benchmark_config.jira_title: Implement/Test API: GET /1.0/kb/accounts/{accountId}/emails - Retrieve an account emails

covered: Valid Request: Success path covered (TC01) — 200 response, Content-Type application/json, and JSON array of AccountEmail objects with expected fields.
Empty Response: Covered (TC02 and TC04) — existing account with no emails and non-existent-but-valid-UUID both return empty JSON array with 200.
Path Parameter Validation: Covered (TC03) — invalid accountId format returns 400 with an error message.
Authorization: Covered as a scenario (TC05) to verify behavior when auth is missing/invalid (401/403).
Query Parameters: Covered (TC07) — extra/unknown query params are ignored and do not break the response.
Large payload/performance: Partially covered (TC08, TC13) — tests for large number of emails and concurrent requests exist and include response-time expectations and concurrency checks.
Security: Covered (TC10, TC11) — basic injection and XSS attempts in accountId are tested.
Robustness: Covered (TC06, TC09, TC12) — service-unavailable, transient network, and unicode/special-character email cases are included.
Backward Compatibility and Accessibility: Covered (TC14, TC15) — legacy client compatibility and accessibility/machine-readable error message expectations are present.
gaps: Pagination: No tests verify pagination behavior (limit/offset/page/next links) for large result sets — TC08 requests large result but does not assert pagination handling.
Caching Behavior: No scenarios validate caching headers or cache-related behavior (ETag, Last-Modified, Cache-Control) or conditional GETs (304).
Rate Limiting / Throttling: No tests for rate limiting or 429 responses when many requests are made in short succession; TC13 checks concurrency but not throttling/429 behavior.
Error Handling - Server Errors: No explicit test for 500/internal server errors (e.g., simulated DB failure) and how error responses are structured.

Schema & Type Validation: While TC01 asserts expected fields, there are no strict schema/type checks (required fields, field types, formats for each AccountEmail field) or negative tests for malformed response bodies.
Content Negotiation / Accept Header: No tests exercise Accept header variations or responses when client requests non-JSON formats.
Consistent Headers Assertion: Content-Type is asserted only in TC01; other scenarios do not consistently assert response headers.
Rate/Load Performance Thresholds: Performance assertions are present for some tests but lack repeatable load-test definitions and thresholds (e.g., sustained load, percentile latencies).
Test Data Lifecycle: Scenarios rely on named UUIDs but do not explicitly include setup/teardown steps for deterministic test fixtures; potential flakiness is unaddressed.
recommendations: Add pagination tests: include scenarios for limit/offset/page-size, verify next/prev links or metadata, and assert behavior when requesting pages beyond available data.
Add caching and conditional GET tests: verify ETag and Cache-Control headers, test conditional GET resulting in 304 Not Modified, and ensure caching headers are appropriate for sensitive data.
Add rate limiting/throttling tests: simulate bursts of requests to assert 429 responses and verify Retry-After header behavior and documentation.
Add server-error and resilience tests: simulate DB/service failures to assert 500 responses, structured error body, and that internal details are not leaked.
Add strict schema validation tests: use JSON schema assertions to check required fields, types, and formats for AccountEmail objects across success and edge cases.
Add content-negotiation tests: verify behavior when Accept header requests application/xml or other unsupported types, and ensure 406 or fallback behavior is correct if applicable.
Make header assertions consistent: assert Content-Type and other relevant headers (Content-Length, Cache-Control, ETag) in all positive and negative scenarios.
Formalize performance/load tests: define repeatable load test jobs with clear thresholds (p95, p99) and include tests for sustained load and burst patterns.
Add deterministic test setup/teardown steps: include explicit creation and cleanup of test accounts and email records in scenarios to avoid dependency on pre-existing data and to reduce flakiness.
